title: Head of Documenta Resigns Amid Antisemitism Scandal
abstract: A crisis at one of the world’s most important art events, in Germany, has deepened with the resignation of its director general.

multimedia.caption: Visitors at the Museum Fridericianum in June during the Documenta contemporary art exhibition in Kassel, Germany.

title: Lend Me a Jukebox Opera. Yuks and Tenor Required.
abstract: “Let’s do a Rossini comedy that doesn’t exist yet,” the head of the Glimmerglass Festival said. Coming soon: Ken Ludwig’s “Tenor Overboard.”

multimedia.caption: From left: Fran Daniel Laucerica, Gregory Feldmann, Armando Contreras and Matthew Pearce in the Glimmerglass Festival’s 2022 production of the world premiere of “Tenor Overboard,” with music by Rossini and book by Ken Ludwig.

title: Review: In ‘Between the Lines,’ Romance Is Thwarted by Reality
abstract: A new Off Broadway musical, based on the best-selling young adult novel by Jodi Picoult and Samantha van Leer, is uneven but sweet, our critic writes.

title: In Rome, a New Museum for Recovered Treasures Before They Return Home
abstract: The Museum of Rescued Art showcases antiquities that were looted or otherwise lost before they go back to institutions in the regions from which they were taken.

multimedia.caption: The Museum of Rescued Art in Rome, which opened last month, is focusing attention on the many art works that have been salvaged, some from natural disasters and others from thieves.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: The Museum of Rescued Art in Rome, which opened last month, is focusing attention on the many art works that have been salvaged, some from natural disasters and others from thieves.

title: Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck Have a Low-Key Midnight Wedding in Las Vegas
abstract: The superstar couple, who got back together last year, waited in line and went to a chapel that Lopez said “graciously stayed open” a few minutes past midnight so they could wed.

multimedia.caption: Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck attending a special screening of the film “Marry Me” in Los Angeles in February. They married in Las Vegas over the weekend.
Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck attending a special screening of the film “Marry Me” in Los Angeles in February. They married in Las Vegas over the weekend.
Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck attending a special screening of the film “Marry Me” in Los Angeles in February. They married in Las Vegas over the weekend.

title: Daisy Edgar-Jones Would Like the Ingénue Phase of Her Career to End Now
abstract: The star of “Where the Crawdads Sing” and “Normal People” has quickly become a Hollywood “It” Girl. But what she craves is longevity.

multimedia.caption: Experiencing her first success during lockdown was strange, Daisy Edgar-Jones said: When someone stared at her, she didn’t know if “they hadn’t seen another human being or if they had seen me in a show.”
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

title: The Knights of Medieval Times Will Carry Union Cards With Their Lances
abstract: The horsemen, courtiers, stablehands and other performers at ye olde New Jersey tourist attraction formed a new kind of medieval guild when they voted to unionize.

multimedia.caption: The actors who play the royals, knights and courtiers of Medieval Times — including, from left, Sean Quigley, Monica Garza and Jonathan Beckas — voted on Friday to form a union.
multimedia.copyright: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

title: With ‘How to Change Your Mind,’ Taking a Trip With Michael Pollan
abstract: Based on the book about psychedelic therapy, a new Netflix docu-series prompted another writer to reach out to Pollan — and dig into his own experiences.
des_facet: How to Change Your Mind (TV Program)
How to Change Your Mind: What the New Science of Psychedelics Teaches Us about Consciousness, Dying, Addiction, Depression, and Transcendence (Book)

multimedia.caption: Michael Pollan with Erika Gagnon, a ceremonial leader. His later-life investigations into psychedelics prompted a New Yorker article, a book and now a Netflix series.

title: The War in Ukraine Is the True Culture War
abstract: With Russia trying to erase Ukraine’s national identity, the fight to preserve, and build upon, Ukraine’s artistic heritage has taken on new urgency.

title: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Found Not Guilty in Federal Gun Case
abstract: Lawyers for the rapper argued that he did not know the weapon was in his car when he was pulled over and arrested on a separate warrant in California last year.

multimedia.caption: YoungBoy Never Broke Again was found not guilty of possessing a firearm and ammunition as a felon in a Los Angeles courtroom on Friday.

title: Soprano Withdraws From Opera, Citing ‘Blackface’ in Netrebko’s ‘Aida’
abstract: The American soprano Angel Blue said she would not appear at the Arena di Verona after the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko and other performers wore dark makeup in its production of “Aida.”

multimedia.caption: The soprano Angel Blue withdrew from an opera at the Arena di Verona in Italy to protest its use of “blackface makeup” in a production of Verdi’s “Aida.”

title: Billy Crystal’s ‘Mr. Saturday Night’ Will End Its Broadway Run
abstract: The stage musical, adapted from a 1992 film, will close Labor Day weekend after five months at the Nederlander Theater.

multimedia.caption: Billy Crystal portrayed the fictional comedian Buddy Young Jr. on HBO specials and Saturday Night Live and then in a Hollywood film before adapting the story into a Broadway musical.

title: Peeling Paint in Hong Kong Reveals Work of Newly Relevant ‘King’
abstract: When he was alive, the graffiti of Tsang Tsou-choi, or the “King of Kowloon,” was considered peculiar and personal. In a radically changed city, his mostly vanished art now has a political charge.

multimedia.caption: When work by the graffiti artist Tsang Tsou-choi re-emerged beneath a Hong Kong bridge, the mundane setting became an unlikely attraction in a city where dissent has been stamped out.
multimedia.copyright: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times

title: A Crop of New Novels About Race and Racism Finds Freedom in Satire
abstract: Authors of color have turned in recent books to humor and surreal conceits to explore racism, identity politics and the pain of being “on the other side of whiteness.”

multimedia.caption: “Many white writers have had the privilege or power of writing another culture,” said Chinelo Okparanta, the author of “Harry Sylvester Bird.” “I wanted to see what it would look like for me to write about a culture that I don’t know.”
multimedia.copyright: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times

title: Jak Knight, Known for the Netflix Series ‘Big Mouth,’ Dies at 28
abstract: Mr. Knight, who had been a successful stand-up comedian for several years, was also a writer for the ABC sitcom “Black-ish.”

title: Mark Fleischman, the Last Impresario of Studio 54, Dies at 82
abstract: He took over the celebrated Manhattan club in the early 1980s and briefly became the self-described “ringleader” of an all-night circus.

multimedia.caption: Mark Fleischman in 1993, a decade after he owned the famed disco Studio 54. “I was thoroughly seduced,” he said, “by the idea of controlling the world’s most important nightclub.”

title: David Dalton, Rock Writer Who Lived the Scene, Dies at 80
abstract: An early writer for Rolling Stone, he traveled in the same circles as the Beatles, Janis Joplin and other stars, witnessing and documenting a time of cultural transformation.

title: L.Q. Jones, Who Played Heavies With a Light Touch, Dies at 94
abstract: His face was familiar, mostly in westerns, during a career that spanned five decades. He also directed the cult film “A Boy and His Dog.”

abstract: Three new books describe Blacks engaged in politics in the South.

title: After 350 Years of Tradition, a Boys’ Choir Now Admits Girls
abstract: The Choir of St. John’s College, Cambridge, is the latest English choir to start including female singers, a move some fear will reduce opportunities for boys.

title: 200 Years Later, Charleston Honors Denmark Vesey’s Attempted Uprising
abstract: Vesey tried to organize an insurrection in 1822 to free enslaved people, but was caught and hanged. Now several prominent Charleston institutions are honoring the bicentenary.
org_facet: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church (Charleston, SC)

multimedia.caption: A monument in honor of Denmark Vesey was erected in Charleston, S.C., in 2014 after facing decades of opposition. It was vandalized in 2021, and was restored this year.

title: Jerome M. Eisenberg, Expert on Antiquities Both Real and Fake, Dies at 92
abstract: He saw himself as a leader in promoting the ethical acquisition of ancient art by museums and collectors, although he also called himself “both an idealist and a hypocrite.”

multimedia.caption: The antiquities dealer Jerome M. Eisenberg in 2004 with a selection from his stock of ancient military helmets. He sold an estimated 40,000 ancient artifacts over the years, and insisted that he never knowingly sold any that were of suspect provenance.

The antiquities dealer Jerome M. Eisenberg in 2004 with a selection from his stock of ancient military helmets. He sold an estimated 40,000 ancient artifacts over the years, and insisted that he never knowingly sold any that were of suspect provenance.

title: Monty Norman, Who Wrote 007’s Memorable Theme, Dies at 94
abstract: He composed the instantly recognizable melody for the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” It has accompanied the agent on his adventures ever since.

multimedia.caption: The opening credit sequence of the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” Monty Norman’s “James Bond Theme” captured the public imagination.
The opening credit sequence of the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” Monty Norman’s “James Bond Theme” captured the public imagination.

title: ‘Marx Can Wait’ Review: A Director Digs Into His Brother’s Death
abstract: In a moving new documentary, the Italian filmmaker Marco Bellocchio gathers his fascinating, aging family members to make sense of their brother’s suicide.

multimedia.caption: Three of the Bellocchio brothers, from left: Marco, the filmmaker; Alberto; and Camillo, who killed himself at 29. In “Marx Can Wait,” the family’s surviving members delve into Camillo’s death.

title: Barbara Kruger: A Way With Words
abstract: She created some of the most memorable works of her era. Now the activist-artist is back with two immersive shows, at MoMA and David Zwirner Gallery.
